Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2014 04:05PM Zillsnot4me wrote: My BMX required three drains. One for each boob and one for my nodes. I think mine came out in a week to ten days. They are annoying but don't hurt. You strip or milk them twice a day. Hand sanitizer is your friend. They will make sure you know how to do it before you leave the hospital.  There are lots of suggestions about different ways to cope with them. Some keep them in a bag, stuff them in pockets or tie them to a lanyard. I carried mine in a dish towel so they didn't touch me. I was hot and it was summer.  Good luck!

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2013 06:30PM Zillsnot4me wrote: Hi Y'all. Just wanted to let you know you can do this. The not knowing is the worst. I had a BMX the end of April. Had port surgery and chemo three weeks after that. Now I'm doing rads. Have two young children. They crawl all over me and are very matter of fact about the whole process. Fatigue is probably the biggest issue for all three phases. You just have to nap and slow down. Very hard for most of us, especially this time of year. If people want to help out, let them. They understand about surgery. They are scared of chemo and don't understand rads. Some would rather cook or clean or run errands or play with your kids. Let them. Don't be afraid to set some rules regarding visits (who or how long) plus tell them your food preferences or allergies. You will be amazed how quickly you feel better. But then you will overdo it and pay the price with some discomfort. These boards are great for support and there's always someone around.

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2014 03:29AM Zillsnot4me wrote: So glad you're better and you went to ER. Agree about those pills when you have an IV. Silly doctors.  I too got very down/low about day 3 after infusion. I had my sister come in and stay for a few days. She would keep me busy or entertained. My mom sent cards that were timed perfectly.   It gets better. You know what to expect and what you need, don't be afraid to ask for help. Most can't wait to help but aren't sure what to do. Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2014 11:20AM Zillsnot4me wrote: Yes it's miserable stuff. I got it with my stIV diagnosis and I'm ned now. Actually lobbied for two extra rounds. You will feel better before your next round so you can gain strength for it. My first round was he'll too.  I piggy backed compezine and zofran every four hours. Watch out for constipation. Had Ativan in my IV. Wonderful.  Ginger tea, chewing gum, chewable alka seltzer, dry cereal and crackers. I felt better after throwing up. Learned if it didn't sound good or smell good, I wasn't eating it.  Also Jin Shin Jytsu helped. Here's a video. I actually had another session today. I truly believe it made a difference in my outcome.  Hang in there!  https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=R11-jiBlbGU&list=PL3...

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2015 09:31AM Zillsnot4me wrote: Kandy. Are you eligible for Medicare because you're 65 or because of ssdi? Under 65 is different. They can deny you a supplement. Triagecancer.org has some good webinars explaining Medicare. Agents only know the plans they are selling. I talked with a state counselor and while helpful, still didn't know everything. Maybe your DHs company could help. I am relying on myself and the Medicare.org website with calls to the companies. You can start this process three months ahead. I recommend it. I was denied within 24 hours. There is a penalty if you do nothing. Interested in the answers. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2013 05:06PM Zillsnot4me wrote: I was one of those that the nausea lasted almost a week but gradually got better each day. I found it best to alternate anti-nausea meds every 4 hours. Tell your MO. But watch out because they can constipate you. Be proactive! The green tea and ginger also helped as did oyster or soup crackers. One after another. I needed to keep something in my stomach or it was worse. Smelling peppermint helped and chewing gum. I couldn't stand dinner cooking so I would hide in the bedroom while they had dinner for first day or two. I always felt better after throwing up. I would know as soon as I smelled or tasted it if it would agree with me. Hang in there. You can do it!

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2016 05:01AM Zillsnot4me wrote: I'm sorry too Rose. What a roller coaster ride complete with n/v. I don't do them for that very reason. My Gma was a Helen. She didn't garden but painted flowers on China and could cook. She did have Violet's in the dining room. She was a homemaker and had proper meals with salad, meat, veg, starch and bread and usually dessert. She and my other Gma were ice creamaholics. I never got that gene. I inherited procrastination and dirty dishes in the sink. My other Gma also had that mad scientist thing in the basement. She had the greenest thumb. Could keep poinsettias going year after year. She cooked from scratch too. Made thanksgiving dinner for 20 people on a regular gas stove. No help, no warming dishes, tiny galley kitchen. Whipped her mashed potatoes with never any lumps. I miss them. It's hard to live up to their examples. Thanks for the memories.

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2015 11:31PM Zillsnot4me wrote: I have lung mets from the get go. Celebrating my two yr anniversary April fools day. I had BMX, chemo and rads in 2013. Now on tamoxifen. Scans clear. My biggest side effect is fatigue. I blame tamoxifen for it. I manage to take care of my two little ones. House cleaning takes a back seat most of the time. I generally lay down most afternoons but don't always sleep. Just have to prioritize. It's very scary right now because you don't have a plan. You can do this. Right now they are going to check everything. I used my time waiting for results and surgery to clean, clean, clean. It kept me busy. They will be checking you out thoroughly. I have just now graduated to every four months for scans but am still seen every two. Hang in there. There's always someone here to help or listen.

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2015 03:05PM - edited Jul 2, 2015 03:05PM by Zillsnot4me Finger holds That link is for Jin Shin Jyutsu videos from my cancer center. I have found them very useful. I practice the strong emotions when I'm anxious in the middle of the night or waiting for an appt. I used the nausea one during chemo and the one for rads every night after treatment. I really believe they work. I get that you feel like there's no one to share your burden since you are an only child. Sometimes friends are better family because you picked them. Stop in here as often as you need.
Posts.Title: scared about my mum angels21 Zillsnot4me

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2015 02:08PM Zillsnot4me wrote: I did ask because we are on holidays in Ireland and would have tried to meet you if you were near. As far as chemo, your nurse will talk to you about diet. Supplements usually aren't recommended. Bland is what I was told. My philosophy is if it sounds good, it should taste good. You can eat healthy after treatment. Some people don't get sick. I was not one of those. I ate a lot of turkey and chicken. Protein is good. I made a green tea and ginger tea. Towards the end I ate white toast and a lot of dry cereal. It was easy on my tummy. Do some of those finger holds yourself. Especially when you are stressed or scared. I used them during treatment and even have my kids use them. I'm on tamoxifen. It's kept me stable, even has healed a couple of bone mets. There's several ladies on hormonals only. Don't discount them. They are powerful drugs.
Posts.Title: scared about my mum angels21 Zillsnot4me

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2015 03:14AM Zillsnot4me wrote: She will need a sleeping cap at night. It's chilly even in the summer. I don't know if you have a cancer association. They gave me mine. It's very soft with no seams. I had a mild headache when it started to come out. I have a pink mesh sun hat that was easy to throw on and a couple of bright scarves and a white baseball cap. I did have wigs but kids had more fun with them. Yes lipstick helps:) My youngest was a baby. Just a year and learning to walk. My boy was 4. He was a little shocked after surgery as I told him how the scar looked after it healed. I forgot about the bandages. It took about a week for him to talk about my bandages. He loves to help. He would stand on the coffee table to put my robe on. He actually said last week that he wishes I would go back on chemo so my hair would be short and curly:) Of course he has no idea what that means. One hand, I'm grateful they were too little to understand. But it also means I may not get to see them graduate, get married or have babies. Just take it one day at a time, go for walks, do the finger holds (especially while trying to sleep or on your way to appts). Eat whatever sounds good, no matter the nutritional content. You need to take care of yourself too.
Posts.Title: scared about my mum angels21 Zillsnot4me

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2015 03:26PM Zillsnot4me wrote: I know you are scared. Try to have faith in your oncologist. Breast cancer is a nasty unpredictable beast. Don't second guess yourself. It will drive you crazy. One of my chemos is the same as you are asking about. It worked on my lungs. The tamoxifen is working on my bones. So far rads took care of my lymph node. But it can change at any time. Be good to yourself so you can be strong for your mom. Don't give up hope. I know it's scary but you'll both feel better once you get started with your new treatment. And remember there's lots of drugs out there and new ones are being tested everyday.
Posts.Title: scared about my mum angels21 Zillsnot4me

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2015 02:35PM Zillsnot4me wrote: I think it's great how you are supporting your mum. The first treatment is hard because of the unknown. Fear may be making her tired. It's not a cake walk but it's doable. She may need more protein. Ask them. Stay on top of the anti nausea meds. They usually give steroids too so she may be wired afterwards. I was able to eat a good meal right after the infusion on the way home. I ate often and small amounts. Bland is your friend. I did six rounds every three weeks. The first week you are tired. The second week you slowly start to feel better. You feel great by the third week, just in time to do it all over again. I got a summer hair cut in anticipation of losing it. I have to say the thought was worse than reality. I did cry in the shower when it came out but I just wore a pretty hat or scarf if I remembered. Two small kids rushing out the door and I'd forget. Wigs were too hot and itchy. You both can do this. I know how scary it is. Take something to occupy your mind or hands. She may sleep during the infusion.

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2016 07:55AM Zillsnot4me wrote: Rose so happy for you! I remember being cold most of the time when I lost my hair. Have you tried ginger "tea"? I found it on these boards when I had n/v. Peel about an inch of fresh ginger and slice into about 2cups of water. Bring to a boil and let steep for 12 min. Add 2 cups cold water and sweeten. I added a green tea bag. It helps and is very refreshing. Would those sea bands that work for motion sickness or that patch they put behind your ear after surgery be options? Ebru you look beautiful. Fresh fish. Yum!

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2013 12:44PM Zillsnot4me wrote: I have a 4 year old and an 18 month. I had prepped the 4 year old about the surgery before hand. I should have done a better job of telling him what to expect me to look like after the BMX with four drains. It took about a week for him to start talking about it. He drew squares in the air to describe my bandages. I knew at that point we were ok. Mine was a big help. He loved having a job like standing on the coffee table to drape a robe over my shoulders. You know him best. And whomever will have him after the visit will have lots of questions to answer. Mine stayed with his aunt and was too busy playing to talk much on the phone. I didn't have him visit but I was only one night. I was late getting to recovery and the pain meds didn't agree with me so I wouldn't have wanted him there. He can give you gentle hugs and kisses on the cheek. Make up a secret handshake. I played footsie with the baby for a long time. She still plays footsie in her high chair. You will be amazed how quickly you feel better.

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2016 09:11PM Zillsnot4me wrote: I've had off/on pain in my hips and knees that wasn't there before cancer. I believe it's from favoring the cancer side. I did PT and it made a difference. Also bought new shoes. My spine mets do not hurt. Before my liver mets were dx I was singing and dancing around the kitchen. I felt great after having my ovaries removed. I was shocked with the dx. My center doesn't look at TMs. My fatigue is different than before but on new meds. I think we know our bodies best. My RO believed me. My new MO seems to believe me. The old one told me not everything is cancer. While that is true, I have never felt this tired or sore and it's all SEs from the cancer preventing meds. So in my book it is cancer related.

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2015 07:06AM Zillsnot4me wrote: My boy was 4. I had the whole ball of wax. I told him I had a booboo on my chest, they were going to cut it out and I would have a scar. He asked if they were going to use a knife. We used the word cancer. I didn't prepare him for the drains so it took him a few days to process when I got home. He told everyone I had a booboo, they were going to use a knife and I had a scarf (scar). We got "summer" haircuts and he wanted to go bald with me. My husband did. I didn't let him. I was afraid he would burn and he's fair skinned. It was a buzz cut though. My baby girl had just turned one when I was diagnosed. She learned to walk while I recuperated from the BMX. The boy now says "when you had cancer...." The baby says "mommy doesn't have nickels (nipples)." If asked where they are, she replies "in the trash". We are matter of fact. Except for not preparing him for how I looked right after surgery, he's been fine. He loved to help. You have to do whats best for your family.
